        {
            first_name: "Tila",
            last_name: "Mong",
            occupation: "Baron Do Sage",
            species: "Kel Dor",
        },
    ];

    let searching = "";

    function searching_algorithm(row) {
        // Instead of fuzzy searching the strings, we're only

        return row.first_name.startsWith(searching);
    }

            last_name: "Daala",
            occupation: "Chief of State",
            species: "Human",
        },

        {
            first_name: "Quinlan",
            last_name: "Vos",
            occupation: "Jedi Master",
            species: "Kiffar",
        },

        {
            first_name: "Tila",
            last_name: "Mong",
            occupation: "Baron Do Sage",
            species: "Kel Dor",
        },
    ];

    function on_first_name_input(row, event) {
        const index = ROWS.findIndex(
            (_row) => row === _row
        );

        // NOTE: You should always clone your array / object data
        // before making mutations! Saves headaches down the road
        ROWS = [...ROWS];

        ROWS[index] = {
            ...row,
            first_name: event.target.value,
        };
    }
</script>

<DataTable
    columns={COLUMNS}
    rows={ROWS}
    palette="accent"
>
    <svelte:fragment let:key let:row>
        {#if key === "first_name"}
            <TextInput
                value={row["first_name"]}
                variation="flush"
                width="100"
                on:input={on_first_name_input.bind(
                    null,
                    row
                )}
            />
        {:else}
            {row[key]}
        {/if}
    </svelte:fragment>
</DataTable>

DataTable.name: columns
DataTable.description: Configures metadata on how DataTable should renders the tabular data.
types: {key: keyof T, text: string, sorting?: boolean, sorting_algorithm?: (a: T[keyof T], b: T[keyof T]) => number}[]

DataTable.name: rows
DataTable.description: Sets the tabular data that DataTable is to render.

DataTable.name: page
DataTable.description: Sets the current page of the pagination.

DataTable.name: paginate
DataTable.description: Enables DataTable to split the tabular data into paged views.

DataTable.name: paging
DataTable.description: Sets how many rows should appear per page.

DataTable.name: sorting
DataTable.description: Sets which row member that DataTable is currently sorting by.

DataTable.name: sorting_mode
DataTable.description: Sets which direction DataTable is sorting the row member by.

DataTable.name: searching
DataTable.description: Sets the current search query that DataTable is using to filter the tabular data.

DataTable.name: searching_algorithm
DataTable.description: Optional custom searching filter. By default, all row members are lowercased and fuzzy searched.

DataTable.name: variation
DataTable.description: Alters how the DataTable renders with various additions.

DataTable.name: default
DataTable.description: Used for customizing how each column in a row is rendered in a table cell.

DataTable.name: next
DataTable.description: Used for customizing the next paging button content.

DataTable.name: previous
DataTable.description: Used for customizing the previous paging button content.

DataTable.name: unsorted
DataTable.description: Used for customizing the not-sorted button content.

DataTable.name: ascending
DataTable.description: Used for customizing the ascending sort button content.

DataTable.name: descending
DataTable.description: Used for customizing the descending sort button content.

    let searching = "";

    function searching_algorithm(row) {
        // Instead of fuzzy searching the strings, we're only

        return row.first_name.startsWith(searching);

By default, DataTable alphabetizes each row's members converted into lower case strings. You can customize this behavior on a per column-basis via the sorting_algorithm member in the column metadata.

<script>
    import {DataTable} from "@kahi-ui/framework";

    const COLUMNS = [
        {
            text: "First Name",
            key: "first_name",
        },

        {
            text: "Last Name",
            key: "last_name",
        },

        {
            text: "Occupation",
            key: "occupation",
            sorting: true,
            sorting_algorithm: (a, b) => {
                // Instead of alphabetizing, we're sorting by length of
                // the `occupation` strings

                return a.length > b.length ? 1 : -1;
            },
        },

        {

            species: "Ortolan",

        {
            first_name: "Mok",
            last_name: "Shaiz",
            occupation: "Mayor",
            species: "Ithorian",
        },

        {
            first_name: "Natasi",
            last_name: "Daala",
            occupation: "Chief of State",
            species: "Human",
        },

        {
            first_name: "Quinlan",
            last_name: "Vos",
            occupation: "Jedi Master",
            species: "Kiffar",
        },

        {
            first_name: "Tila",
            last_name: "Mong",
            occupation: "Baron Do Sage",
            species: "Kel Dor",
        },
    ];

    function on_first_name_input(row, event) {
        const index = ROWS.findIndex(
            (_row) => row === _row
        );

        // NOTE: You should always clone your array / object data
        // before making mutations! Saves headaches down the road
        ROWS = [...ROWS];

        ROWS[index] = {
            ...row,
            first_name: event.target.value,
        };
    }
</script>

<DataTable
    columns={COLUMNS}
    rows={ROWS}
    palette="accent"
>
    <svelte:fragment let:key let:row>
        {#if key === "first_name"}
            <TextInput
                value={row["first_name"]}
                variation="flush"
                width="100"
                on:input={on_first_name_input.bind(
                    null,
                    row
                )}
            />
        {:else}
            {row[key]}
        {/if}
    </svelte:fragment>
</DataTable>
